What Are the Most Popular Roofing Materials in the USA?

Homeowners across the country choose roofing materials based on performance, cost, and style. Here’s a practical look at the top five options and why each is popular.

Asphalt Shingles: Affordable and Versatile

Asphalt shingles remain the most common residential roofing material because they balance cost, looks, and ease of installation. They are available in three-tab and architectural (dimensional) varieties. Architectural shingles provide better wind resistance and a more attractive profile than three-tab shingles.

Modern asphalt shingles include impact-resistant and cool-roof options that reflect heat and extend service life. Proper ventilation and underlayment are essential to maximize lifespan.

  • Best For: Most suburban and urban homes where budget and aesthetics are priorities.

  • Drawbacks: Typical lifespan of 20–30 years (varies by product and climate). May require replacement sooner in extreme-weather regions.

  • Pro Insight: Choose architectural shingles with a Class 3 or 4 hail rating and a high-wind warranty for improved durability.

Metal Roofing: Durable, Energy-Efficient, and Recyclable

Metal roofing — including standing seam, corrugated, and metal shingles — offers exceptional longevity (40–70 years for many systems) and excellent wind and fire resistance. Painted and coated metal roofs with cool-roof finishes reflect solar radiation, reducing cooling costs in hot climates.

Metal is a popular choice for low-slope and steep-slope roofs and for homeowners seeking a modern look plus long-term value. While the upfront cost is higher, metal often outperforms other materials over the life of the home.

  • Best For: Homes in hot or variable climates and homeowners wanting a long-lasting, low-maintenance roof.

  • Drawbacks: Higher initial cost; can dent from large hail unless thicker gauges or impact-rated panels are used.

  • Pro Insight: Combine metal roofing with high-quality insulation and underlayment to reduce noise and improve energy performance.

Tile Roofing: Classic Appearance with Exceptional Longevity

Clay and concrete tiles are common in the Southwest, California, and coastal areas because of their heat resistance and visual appeal. Tile roofs can last 50+ years and resist salt-air corrosion better than many other materials.

Tile is heavy, so homes may require reinforced framing. Modern concrete tiles offer a cost-effective alternative to clay, while synthetic tiles mimic the look with reduced weight.

  • Best For: Mediterranean, Spanish, and mission-style homes; hot climates where reflective performance matters.

  • Drawbacks: High upfront cost and structural considerations due to weight. Fragility under heavy impact is possible with traditional clay tiles.

  • Pro Insight: Inspect underlayment and flashing regularly; salt and coastal climates can accelerate underlayment wear if not properly installed.

Slate Roofing: Long-Term, Low-Maintenance Elegance

Natural slate is one of the longest-lasting roofing materials available, often exceeding 100 years when properly installed. Slate is fire-resistant, low-maintenance, and highly attractive on historic and high-end homes.

Because slate is very heavy and costly, many homeowners opt for synthetic slate products that provide a similar look with lower weight and cost, though with shorter lifespans than natural slate.

  • Best For: Historic or premium homes where longevity and authenticity are priorities.

  • Drawbacks: Very high installation cost and structural reinforcement may be required.

  • Pro Insight: Use certified slate roof installers experienced with historic roof systems to avoid installation issues that lead to premature failure.

Flat Roofing: Functional for Modern and Urban Properties

Flat and low-slope roofs are common on modern urban homes and additions. Materials such as TPO, EPDM, and modified bitumen are widely used. A well-installed flat roof can support rooftop decks, green roofs, or solar installations.

Drainage design and membrane quality are critical. Flat roofs require proactive maintenance to prevent ponding water and membrane degradation.

  • Best For: Contemporary homes, urban infill, and properties planning rooftop use like solar panels or gardens.

  • Drawbacks: Higher maintenance needs and sensitivity to drainage issues if not designed and installed correctly.

  • Pro Insight: Choose high-quality membranes and design falls for drainage. Regular inspections extend membrane life and prevent leaks.

Choosing the Right Roofing Material: Factors to Consider

To select the best roofing material for your home, consider climate, home architecture, budget, lifespan expectations, and local building codes. Additional factors include:

  • Climate Adaptability: Temperature extremes, hail, wind, and salt exposure affect material choice. For example, metal and slate perform well in wind-prone areas while tile and clay are suited to hot climates.

  • Energy Efficiency: Cool-roof coatings and reflective materials can lower cooling costs. Consider insulation and ventilation when evaluating overall energy performance.

  • Aesthetics and Local Style: Match roofing material to your home’s architectural style to preserve curb appeal and resale value.

  • Lifespan vs. Budget: Compare lifecycle costs. A higher upfront investment in metal, tile, or slate may yield lower total cost over decades compared with repeated asphalt shingle replacements.
